name: Trustworthiness Ranking with Uncertain Information
organizedBy: Guiseppe Primiero (Milan)
description:
Trustworthiness assessment of information sources is a useful alternative to automated fact-checking for the detection of disinformation online. In cases like experts' debates, the use of trustworthiness metrics on sources is a useful proxy for establishing the truthfulness of contents. In this talk I shall present recent work [1,2] on an algorithmic model for automatically generating a dynamic trustworthiness hierarchy among information sources based on a logical framework for agent-based trust evaluation [3] and enhanced by several parameters, including fact-checking. The method is a helpful tool for laypeople to navigate experts’ debates, which can also be supported by graphical aids. Current work is devoted to a probabilistic extension to model debates where the ability to reach information depends on its frequency, determining uncertainty in the value of trust associated to its source and a level of confidence in the resulting hierarchy.

[1] Davide Ceolin, Francesca Doneda, Giuseppe Primiero: Computable Trustworthiness Ranking of Medical Experts in Italy during the SARS-CoV-19 Pandemic. GoodIT 2021: 271-276

[2] G. Primiero, D. Ceolin & F. Doneda (2023) A computational model for assessing experts’ trustworthiness, Journal of Experimental & Theoretical Artificial Intelligence, DOI: 10.1080/0952813X.2023.2183272

[3] Giuseppe Primiero: A logic of negative trust. J. Appl. Non Class. Logics 30(3): 193-222 (2020)

name: Computer Says No”, But Should We Listen?
organizedBy: Jonne Maas
description: AI systems have become ubiquitous and indispensable in the functioning of modern digital societies. Consequently, we inevitably act on the outputs of these algorithmic systems, thereby attributing to them a form of algorithmic authority. However, is this algorithmic authority legitimate? I assess this question on the basis of democratic accounts of legitimate authority. AI systems are embedded in how they are developed and deployed, which is predominantly done by private, for-profit companies outside of democratic control. In those cases, I argue that algorithmic authority is currently illegitimate. This becomes particularly problematic when we have no choice but to act on a system's output, such as with Automated Decision Systems. As a result, the development and deployment of AI systems should be grounded in democratically legitimate design procedures.

name: Artificial Intelligence: The Brand That Wouldn't Die.
organizedBy: Prof. Thomas Haigh (Professor of History at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee and Comenius Visiting Professor at the University of Siegen)
description: The  history of AI is the history of an overhyped brand that has only very  recently come to signify a set of deployable technologies with broad application and clear, if somewhat horrifying, purposes. Over almost seventy years  it’s been attached to a range of loosely related projects, none of which  have yet come close to delivering on the promise of creating computer  systems with human-like intelligence. One insider characterized the story of AI as “the history of failed ideas.” Yet in  the process of failing, early AI researchers made vital but incidental  contributions to the development of computer technology and computer  science. In this talk I’ll ask where did discussion of artificial intelligence come from, why was it so attractive to  researchers and sponsors, and what did the lofty rhetoric of machine  intelligence have to do with the actual practice of artificial  intelligence as it institutionalized through research labs, curricula, textbooks, and professional associations? I’ll also  look for continuities and discontinuities between our own moment and  earlier cycles of AI hype and disillusionment.

name: Heidegger's Philosophy of Science
organizedBy: Prof. Patricia Glazebrook (Washington State University)
description: Although a great deal of attention is paid to Heidegger’s later critique of technology, no one has systematically studied how he understood “science.” Many [..] will be surprised to learn [...] that Heidegger developed the essentials of a fairly sophisticated philosophy of science, one that in many ways invites comparison with that of Thomas Kuhn.

name: What an Algorithm is
organizedBy: Prof. Robin K. Hill (University of Wyoming)
description: The algorithm, a building block of computer science, is defined from an intuitive and pragmatic point of view, through a methodological lens of philosophy rather than that of formal computation. The treatment extracts properties of abstraction, control, structure, finiteness, effective mechanism, and imperativity, and intentional aspects of goal and preconditions. The focus on the algorithm as a robust conceptual object obviates issues of correctness and minimality. Neither the articulation of an algorithm nor the dynamic process constitute the algorithm itself. Analysis for implications in computer science and philosophy reveals unexpected results, new questions, and new perspectives on current questions, including the relationship between our informally construed algorithms and Turing machines. Exploration in terms of current computational and philosophical thinking invites further developments.

name: Explaining AI Through the Scientific Perspective
organizedBy: Prof. Lena Kästner (Bayreuth University)
description: Modern artificial intelligence (AI) systems are often complex and opaque. At the same time, they are becoming increasingly prevalent in our lives. As a result, there is an increasing demand to make AI systems explainableand their behaviour intelligible. Recent work primarily approaches this problem by employing specific explainability methods to aid in-context understanding. We think, however, that important desiderata such as safety and reliability might be best satisfied through the increase of expert understanding with respect to how AI systems work. We suggest this requires research from the scientific perspective. This approach starts from the premise that once AI systems become sufficiently complex, they are best investigated and explained through the same lens as biological organisms. Accordingly, this work seeks to characterise the functional structure that emerges in AI systems through training. As we will describe, researchers pursuing this approach adopt strategies for discovery that have proved successful in the life sciences, such as pattern recognition, functional decomposition, localization, and systematic manipulation. In this talk, we discuss the promises and limitations of the scientific approach to understanding AI systems. We contend that uncovering their emergent structure plays an important and underappreciated role in solving the explainability problem in AI.

name: The seductions of Clarity
organizedBy: Prof. Christopher Thi Nguyen (Bern University)
description: The feeling of clarity can be dangerously seductive. It is the feeling associated with understanding things. And we use that feeling, in the rough-and-tumble of daily life, as a signal that we have investigated a matter sufficiently. The sense of clarity functions as a thought-terminating heuristic. In that case, our use of clarity creates significant cognitive vulnerability, which hostile forces can try to exploit. If an epistemic manipulator can imbue a belief system with an exaggerated sense of clarity, then they can induce us to terminate our inquiries too early – before we spot the flaws in the system. How might the sense of clarity be faked? Let’s first consider the object of imitation: genuine understanding. Genuine understanding grants cognitive facility. When we understand something, we categorize its aspects more easily; we see more connections between its disparate elements; we can generate new explanations; and we can communicate our understanding. In order to encourage us to accept a system of thought, then, an epistemic manipulator will want the system to provide its users with an exaggerated sensation of cognitive facility. The system should provide its users with the feeling that they can easily and powerfully create categorizations, generate explanations, and communicate their understanding. And manipulators have a significant advantage in imbuing their systems with a pleasurable sense of clarity, since they are freed from the burdens of accuracy and reliability.

name: The artificial intelligence revolution in science?
organizedBy: Domink Gersdorfer (Stuttgart)
description: The use of machine learning and other second-wave AI techniques  in scientific research has become very successful lately. One often cited example is AlphaFold, which determines the three-dimensional structure of proteins. Such undertakings have led many commentators to claim that we are in the midst of a scientific revolution. Some even go so far as to consider the possibility of fully automated science in the near future and argue that these developments will render traditional, theory based science a relic of the past. These claims raise several questions: What kinds of AI are employed in science? What is meant by 'revolution'? And which parts of science are considered? My talk will therefore be divided into three parts, each of which will address one of the questions: The first part will examine, what makes second-wave AI so successful compared to GOFAI (Good Old-Fashioned Artificial Intelligence) and where it falls short. Further the key differences between the different types of AI will be elaborated in order to understand better where and how AI can be utilized in science. The second part addresses the areas of the research process where AI is used, such as in developing new hypotheses and searching for patterns in Big Data, as well as the differences and similarities between disciplines that use AI. The goal is to comprehend the scope of AI in science: How much of the research process can be covered by AI? The final part will address the question of whether the use of AI science justifies the revolutionary rhetoric that accompanies it. For this, the notion of scientific revolution will be considered from Kuhnian and post-Kuhnian perspectives. These will then be applied to the considerations elaborated in parts one and two with respect to scope and potential applications in order to make a classification and assessment of the AI revolution in science.

name: Deceptive AI
organizedBy: Prof. Dr. Wally Smith and Peta Masters (University of Melbourne)
description:
What does it mean for a machine to deceive? 
Deception is inherent in many conceptions of Artificial Intelligence, from Turing’s original formulation of whether a machine can think, to dystopian visions of machines outwitting their human creators. We consider what it means for a machine to deceive, and describe various forms of deceptive AI that have been implemented and studied. To gain perspective on their significance, we categorize the methods they use according to recognizably human deceits: imitating, obfuscating, tricking, calculating and framing. While these developments demonstrate that some aspects of deceptive behaviour can indeed be delegated to machines, AI systems still fall short of sophisticated human deception. To explore this gap we present an analysis of techniques used by stage magicians to deceive their audiences, and consider whether and how machines might come to be truly deceptive in similar ways.

name: Formal Representations of Doxastic Suspension

name: Understanding climate change with statistical downscaling and machine learning
organizedBy: Vincent Lam (Bern University)
description: Machine learning methods have recently created high expectations in the climate modelling context in view of addressing climate change, but they are often considered as non-physics-based ‘black boxes’ that may not provide any understanding. However, in many ways, understanding seems indispensable to appropriately evaluate climate models and to build confidence in climate projections. Relying on two case studies, we compare how machine learning and standard statistical techniques affect our ability to understand the climate system. For that purpose, we put five evaluative criteria of understanding to work: intelligibility, representational accuracy, empirical accuracy, coherence with background knowledge, and assessment of the domain of validity.We argue that the two families of methods are part of the same continuum where these various criteria of understanding come in degrees, and that therefore machine learning methods do not necessarily constitute a radical departure from standard statistical tools, as far as understanding is concerned.

name: Cultivating epistemic routines for navigating toxic epistemic environments
organizedBy: Axel Gelfert / TU Berlin
description: Much ink has been spilt on the nefarious aspects of creating and disseminating fake news, its adverse effects on the public sphere and the violation of trust it engenders. Yet, given that the socio-epistemic dynamics that underlie fake news are here to stay, it is equally important to think about how we can navigate treacherous informational environments. I argue that this requires the cultivation of epistemic routines that reduce our exposure to misleading and deceptive information, while at the same time continuing to allow us to partake in the collective growth of knowledge. Shifting the focus to epistemic routines steers a middle path between two purported solutions that have received much attention: viz., between emphasizing the individual’s responsibility to ‘think critically and check one’s sources’ and advocating technological tweaks (such as automated fact-checking). While epistemic agents ought to be held responsible for the epistemic routines they commit themselves to, there is also a collective need for making the predictable effects of such choices transparent to individuals, wherever this is technologically possible.

name: Ampliative Deductive Proof in Mathematical Practice: Lessons from Kant and Frege
organizedBy: Danielle Macbeth / Haverford College
description: Mathematicians in their practice appear to establish fully contentful, non-trivial truths that extend our knowledge. And at least in some cases they do so through a course of deductive reasoning from the contents of concepts, from definitions. Building on the work of Kant and Frege, I aim to clarify how this works, how it is that by deductive reasoning on the basis of definitions of mathematical concepts one can discover substantive and novel mathematical truths.

name: The optimist, the curious and the sceptic: Three earth scientist perspectives on machine learning
organizedBy: Uwe Ehret, Erwin Zehe, Jan Cermat / Karlsruhe Institute of Technology
description: In this talk, we present the perspectives of three earth scientists on the uses, benefits and limitations of  machine learning (ML) approaches applied to their discipline. Jan Cermak provides an optimistic view based on successful applications of ML approaches for exploiting big data in remote sensing and atmospheric modelling. Uwe Ehret acknowledges the recent success of ML approaches in hydrological modelling, but argues that further development of ML models should be based on rigorous out-of-sample evaluation, and with a focus on interpretability and parsimony. Erwin Zehe, physicist by training, offers a sceptical view, making the case for reasoning and modelling based on first principles

name: Algorithmic Regimes
organizedBy: Dawid Kasprowicz, Daniel Wenz, Gabriele Gramelsberger, CSS Lab
description: The planned network "Algorithmic Regimes: Interactions, Methods and Politics" aims to examine the current changes in scientific and non-scientific practices of knowledge production caused by the dissemination and rise of algorithmic, (big) data-driven systems. We call theses systems 'algorithmic regimes'. These current changes involve shifts in the methodology and epistemology of knowledge production, especially in the ways in which scientific knowledge and non-scientific knowledge are entangled and/or distinguished. The interdisciplinary network approaches the emerging 'algorithmic regimes' by focusing on media practices like coding, algorithm-design and -use to ask how these practices reshape, extend but also complicate the understanding of scientific and non-scientific knowledge production in an era of algorithmic big data-analysis.

name: How to Model Artificial Sociality: A Proposal
organizedBy: Johanna Seibt / Aarhus University
description: While the ethical problems of AI and social robotics have been foregrounded during the past decade, this talk addresses the conceptual problems that arise when artificial agents present themselves as social agents. With focus on social robotics in particular, I argue that in the current research situation we first need (philosophical) ontology and then ethics--more precise descriptions of human social interactions with robots will enable us to produce the sort of empirical data that can ground detailed ethical recommendations. I introduce the descriptive framework OASIS (Ontology of Asymmetric Social Interactions) which is based on three constructional ideas: degrees of simulation, levels of sociality, and perspectivalness.  As I try to show, OASIS offere simple, yet sufficiently expressive and precise descriptive tools that can facilitate the interdisciplinary integration of Human-Robot Interaction Research.

name: Kant's Cognitive Architecture
organizedBy: Richard Evans / Imperial College London and Google Deep Mind
description: In this talk, I will describe a machine implementation of assimilative apperception that is based on Kant’s discussion of the "synthetic unity of apperception" in the Critique of Pure Reason. Imagine a machine, equipped with various sensors. Perhaps it has some light sensors, perhaps a microphone, perhaps some touch sensors. The machine receives a stream of sensory input, and must "make sense" of this stream. – But what does it mean, exactly, for a robot to “make sense” of the sensory stream? In machine learning, this is called the "unsupervised learning problem", and it is still relatively under-explored and misunderstood. I will argue that the answer to this contemporary question lies, hiding in plain sight, in the first half of the First Critique. Our computer agent assimilates information by constructing a theory that explains the sensory stream and that satisfies four unity conditions. First, the objects must be unified in space. Second, the predicates must be unified in the "space of reasons" by featuring in mutual incompatibility relations. Third, the various propositions must be unified into a "moment" (a consistent and complete cluster of propositions that together represent a single slice of time). The fourth and final unity condition is that moments must be unified into a sequence by causal rules. Apperceiving a sensory sequence means constructing a theory that explains the sequence and satisfies the four unity conditions. This is a form of program synthesis, but it is unsupervised program synthesis. In this talk, I will not focus on the gory technical details of the unsupervised program synthesis system, but on the general architecture, the underlying Kantian principles that inspired the architecture, and on a diverse range of experiments which show the versatility of the approach.

name: Fairness in Machine Learning(Samira Samadi / Max-Planck Institute for intelligent Systems Tübingen)
organizedBy: Samira Samadi / Max-Planck Institute for intelligent Systems Tübingen
description: I will give a general talk on this topic for a broad audience, introducing the issues of bias in machine learning models and how to detect these issues and then conclude with brief discussion on what researchers who work on fairness in machine learning (and more broadly ethics in AI) do to address these issues and to design more ethical machine learning algorithms.
location: Human Technology Centre, RWTH Aachen and online on Zoom

name: Explainable Artificial Intelligence and the Problems of Philosophy(Carlos Zednik / TU Eindhoven)
organizedBy: Carlos Zednik / TU Eindhoven
description: The Black Box Problem arises because machine learning methods yield algorithms whose behavior is difficult to predict, interpret, and control. Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) is dedicated to solving this problem. In the first part of this talk, I will introduce several different XAI methods and evaluate the extent to which they can actually be used to solve the Black Box Problem. In the second part of this talk, I will consider whether these same methods can also be used to solve a variety of more traditional philosophical problems: from philosophy of science, the problem of inferring causal relationships; from ethics, the problem of attributing moral responsibility for the behavior of autonomous systems; and from philosophy of mind, the problem of identifying genuine kinds of machine intelligence.
location: Human Technology Centre, RWTH Aachen and online on Zoom

name: The status and limits of scientific learning by machine.
organizedBy: Ben Jantzen/ Virginia Tech
description:
Kolloquium in Cooperation with the Research Group "Modelling Trust" of the HLRS Stuttgart. Abstract:
There is concern that the methods of machine learning (ML) offer limited support for scientific inference. The worry is that while ML methods are apt for spotting hidden patterns in large, complex datasets, the output of such methods is neither readily interpretable nor accompanied by clear error bounds or degrees of confidence. More broadly, science generally aims at causal knowledge, and the statistical methods of ML are not reliable guides to causal relations. However, if ML is understood broadly to encompass all algorithms that learn from empirical experience, these fears are misguided. In this talk, I outline the remarkable progress over the last three decades in finding algorithmic solutions to a series of scientific inference problems: (1) combining causal knowledge with statistical learning techniques, (2) discovering causal structure, (3) identifying laws of nature, and (4) inventing novel scientifically salient variables. I argue that these advances represent a powerful armamentarium for automated scientific discovery. But this armamentarium is incomplete. I close by indicating an overlooked step in experimental inquiry that remains poorly characterized and consequently cannot yet be automated.

name: Semiotic Complexities Theory & Analysis
organizedBy: Irene Mittelberg, Geert Brône, Kurt Feyaerts, Paul Sambre, Gabriele Gramelsberger, Martin Thiering in Zusammenarbeit mit der International Association for Cognitive Semiotics
description: Cognitive semiotics is the study of meaning-making, both in language and by means of other sign vehicles, as well as in perception, and in action. Cognitive semiotics investigates the properties of our meaningful interactions with our surroundings in all domains. We integrate perspectives, methods and insights from cognitive science, cognitive linguistics and semiotics, placing signs and sign use (in the broadest sense) into the wider context of cognitive, social, and neurobiological processes, using experimental methods, as well as classical text analysis and theory.

name: Nachwuchstagung "Künstliche Intelligenz und Weltverstehen"
organizedBy: Martin Carrier, Julia Engelschalt, Rainer Godel, Gabriele Gramelsberger, Franz Kather, Carsten Reinhardt, Christian Vater in Zusammenarbeit mit dem Leopoldina-Zentrum für Wissenschaftsforschung und INSIST Interdisciplinary Network for Studies Investigating Science and Technology
description: Künstliche Intelligenz verändert unsere Welt. Sie steht im Zentrum tiefgreifender technischer und medialer Veränderungen. Ihre vielfältigen Anwendungsmöglichkeiten haben schon jetzt Auswirkungen auf zahlreiche Lebensbereiche, von Politik und Wirtschaft über die Wissenschaft bis in die Alltagswelt hinein. Künstliche Intelligenz formt dabei unser Handeln in der Welt ebenso wie unsere Vorstellungen von der Welt—und nicht zuletzt von uns selbst. Welche Möglichkeiten, aber auch Herausforderungen ergeben sich aus den Veränderungen, die die KI mit sich bringt? Welche praktischen, sozialen, rechtlichen und ethischen Fragen müssen im Umgang mit KI bedacht und womöglich neu verhandelt werden? Und: Wie kann die Wissenschafts- und Technikforschung zu einer gesamtgesellschaftlichen Reflexion über KI beitragen? Diesen und anderen Fragen geht die gemeinsame Tagung des Leopoldina-Zentrums für Wissenschaftsforschung und der Nachwuchsinitiative INSIST nach und bietet in verschiedenen Formaten Raum zur Diskussion über die Rolle Künstlicher Intelligenzen in gegenwärtigen und zukünftigen Gesellschaften.
location: Leopoldina-Zentrums für Wissenschaftsforschung, Emil-Abderhalden-Straße 36, 06108 Halle (Saale), Lesesaal

name: Operator & User Empowerment in Times of AI
organizedBy: Frank Piller, RWTH Innovation Management, Thomas Bergs, RWTH WZL, Gabriele Gramelsberger, CSS Lab
description: The goal of this workshop is to bring stakeholders from industry, society, research, and politics together to discuss the needs and possibilities of future collaborations of humans, AI and machines for Industry 4.0. We want to learn from experiences from different industries and application areas, discuss concepts of operator (user) empowerment in production and other domains, understand the concept of fair use of AI, but also identify open fields for research, development, and policy making.

name: Modeling Trust. An AI lie detector (iBorderCtrl)
organizedBy: Andreas Kaminski, CSS Lab
description: The workshop discusses the EU-funded project iBorderCtrl in which computer technology is developed to screen persons who want to immigrate into the EU. iBorderCtrl is a test battery that spans over biometric modules, evaluations of Social Media Data and Risk Based Assessment Tools). One of these modules is an AI-lie detector, named Automatic Deception Detection System (ADDS). The workshop focuses on the ADDS and its implementation on three border locations of the EU (Latvia, Ungary and Greece).
location: Human Technology Centre, RWTH Aachen and online on Zoom

name: Datennaturen
organizedBy: Gabriele Gramelsberger in Zusammenarbeit mit der Computer Signals Research Group
description: Daten sind nie einfach gegeben, sondern werden in vielfältigen Prozeduren hergestellt, berechnet und verteilt. Dies gilt insbesondere auch im digitalen Datenraum, der entgegen der Annahme, das Prozessieren von Daten sei eine rein logisch-mathematische Angelegenheit, auf massiven Infrastrukturen aufbaut und den Daten damit einen physischen Körper anhaftet.  Die interdisziplinär angelegte Tagung Datennaturen versteht Daten selbst als Organismen, die bestimmte Lebensbedingungen benötigen und einem Lebenszyklus (data life cycle) unterworfen sind. Sie geht von Praktiken der Datenherstellung und der Datenarbeit anhand konkreter Beispiele aus. Die darin auftauchenden «Naturen» von Daten als deren stoffliche und genealogische Beschaffenheit, ihre technisch-infrastrukturellen Bedingtheiten von Herstellung und Prozessierung sowie ihren Eigensinn im Zusammenspiel der Akteure diskutiert sie im erweiterten Kreis mit Biologen, Wissenschaftsforschenden, Künstlerinnen sowie Kunst- und Medienwissenschaftlerinnen.

name: Infrastructures of Science
organizedBy: Daniela Zetti, ETH Zürich, and Gabriele Gramelsberger, CSS Lab
description: Archives, collections, labs and machine parks are well known institutions that promote scientific research. From the 19th century on they have been developing into large scale research systems organizing methods, instruments and scientists’ work. In the last decades we are witnessing that sciences have become more and more computer-based. Obviously, data centers, networks and platforms are indispensable facilities for research, they are complementing and reconfiguring traditional technologies. In a historical perspective, digital infrastructures offer an unprecedented generalizability: they stimulate the production and circulation of methodological knowledge across a broad spectrum of academic disciplines. The interdisciplinary Summer School investigates the history and philosophy of digital infrastructures. How do infrastructures affect science? And how do sciences configure their technologies?

name: Many Faces of Logic - Workshop

description: The aim of this workshop is to introduce the work of Johan van Benthem, its applications, and ongoing developments to an interdisciplinary public. This includes but is not limited to the areas of logic, mathematics and philosophy, as well as of informatics, AI-research, cognitive sciences, theory of learning and every discipline that analyses social dynamics of any kind.
